One more thing like I also had a confusion between Ropar and Mandi I found out that according to their senior who got the highest package in 2024 he told me that acad at Ropar is very hectic and a lot of stuff is not useful unlike IIIT H where acad is hectic but the courses are very good and they benefit in future so don't think of it that way.You should not compare by placement stats only coz those are just initial they don't determine your career as such you should also think that these 4 years won't be repeated and think where you can explore new stuff at the same time enjoy yourself as well coz I always say you realize how good Mandi is after you reach home .

i just checked curriculum for IIT Ropar Mnc and compared it with IIT Mandi Mnc and found a few interesting points:
1. Mandi has a lot more free electives credits than ropar in the course which you can choose according to your liking.
2. ⁠Ropar’s curriculum has lot more generic and non-core courses like geography and environmental science even till their sixth semester which, honestly, prove out to be useless. On the other hand, Mandi’s curriculum offers more branch specific courses from 1st year itself which are more industry-oriented.
3. Important ⁠Courses like Machine Learning and Data Structures are offered in the initial years of study contrary to Ropar where these courses are offered in 3rd year of Study.
Consider these points before making any choice if academics and placements matter to you.

Here’s a breakdown to help you decide between IIT Mandi Bio, IIT BHU Pharmaceutical, and IIT Patna Civil, based on career scope, campus, flexibility, and interests:
---
🔬 1. IIT Mandi – Bioengineering
Pros:
Upcoming interdisciplinary field (bio + tech).
Mandi is improving rapidly; good infrastructure and exposure.
Research-focused institute; decent global opportunities.
Coding electives are possible (especially in 2nd year onwards).
Cons:
Less core jobs in India currently.
You’ll need to switch to coding or go abroad for better placements if not interested in biotech core.
Best for: Someone open to research, coding, or switching to interdisciplinary tech (bioinformatics, AI in healthcare).
---
💊 2. IIT BHU – Pharmaceutical Engineering
Pros:
Old, reputed IIT; very good alumni network.
Option to shift career paths via coding or analytics if needed.
Strong in pharma core (good for MS/PhD or jobs like DRDO, pharma companies).
Cons:
Limited core jobs unless you aim for pharma R&D or higher studies.
Heavy chemistry/chemical engineering base—can be dry if you're not interested.

Best for: Someone open to research, coding, or switching to interdisciplinary tech (bioinformatics, AI in healthcare).
---
💊 2. IIT BHU – Pharmaceutical Engineering
Pros:
Old, reputed IIT; very good alumni network.
Option to shift career paths via coding or analytics if needed.
Strong in pharma core (good for MS/PhD or jobs like DRDO, pharma companies).
Cons:
Limited core jobs unless you aim for pharma R&D or higher studies.
Heavy chemistry/chemical engineering base—can be dry if you're not interested.
Best for: Students open to either core pharma or using IIT BHU’s reputation to pivot (coding, MBA, UPSC, etc.).
---
🏗️ 3. IIT Patna – Civil Engineering
Pros:
Core jobs in PSUs, infrastructure firms.
IIT Patna has decent placement growth, though not elite yet.
Civil is relatively stable and known in India.
Cons:
Less flexibility in shifting to coding unless you put in extra effort.
Core civil jobs may have lower pay unless it’s PSU.
Best for: Someone okay with core engineering or PSU goal, or ready to work hard to switch fields.
---
✅ Priority Order Based on General Flexibility + Career Scope (and if you are not into core)
> 1. IIT Mandi Bio (more flexible; better coding and research options)
2. IIT BHU Pharma (older IIT, good brand, can switch with effort)
3. IIT Patna Civil (least flexible unless you're PSU/core-focused)
---
🧠 Final Advice:
If you're interested in tech/coding, prefer Mandi Bio (more flexibility and better environment for coding).
If you want brand + options for MBA/Govt/PhD, BHU Pharma is solid.
If you're okay with Civil/PSU or will do coding on the side rigorously, Patna Civil is fine.
Let me know your interests (coding, core, UPSC, abroad, etc.), and I can personalize it more!

[06/06/25, 1:52:17 PM] Ritvik Garg: The restriction is that "the combination of the elective courses is less than 40% of the discipline core courses of a specific branch"
I'll explain with an example....so suppose CSE students have 3 core courses A, B, C
40% of 3 is 1.2...this means that you only get to choose 1 core course of CSE
Moreover, you can't just choose any one out of A, B or C....it may be that the professor taking course C doesn't allow you to sit in that course (maybe because you haven't done some prerequisites for that course), so you can't choose course C ‎<This message was edited>

[06/06/25, 2:43:29 PM] ~ Arpit Agarwal: Bro I have read the FAQs pdf, just want to know since there are no placement stats for this branch, what are the possible options where we can land after the graduation, and if someone is doing specialization in robotics I want to know how hectic will it be , also last year after 5th round ge closed at approx 10.8 k , my rank is 10.6k , but if more people are considering it now, are there any chances  i may get it this year..
I m also considering mandi civil as well but since ge is new branch but has better cutoff , i m confused which one should be good for me.. pls help should I keep ge over civil? Because civil i will get most probably1.Modern curriculum aligned with the future
IIT Mandi’s EE curriculum is genuinely future-focused. Courses like FDP (Freedom of Design Practicum), DP (Design Practicum), and three separate, in-depth Data Science courses make the learning practical and relevant. We also have electives in Machine Learning and Deep Learning that are available as free electives, so even core EE students can comfortably dive into modern domains. 2.Modern infrastructure and cutting-edge labs
At Mandi, seniors and professors are quite approachable. UG students here don’t just do research for namesake — many have actually published research papers while still in their BTech. That kind of early exposure is a huge boost whether you’re planning for MS, PhD, or research-based internships like DAAD or MITACS. 4.Flexible and open course structure
You’re not bound by a rigid syllabus. The EE department allows you to customize your path — whether it’s focusing on Embedded Systems, VLSI, Power, or even choosing CSE electives. You can even officially pursue a minor in CSE which opens up even more options in AI/ML, software, or research fields.,5.Hackathon culture and highly active clubs
We have a lot of hackathons, not just basic ones but those conducted by companies that are part of the Inter-IIT ecosystem. This keeps the competitive and building spirit alive. On top of that, our technical clubs — whether it's robotics, aeromodelling, coding, or E-cell — are genuinely active, organizing events almost every other week. It’s the kind of place where you always have something to work on or learn from. 6.Beautiful campus with fewer distractions
